title: How to Season Asparagus

steps.headline: Chop up fresh herbs for an aromatic addition to your asparagus.
steps.description: Use any combination of parsley, chives, rosemary, thyme, basil, oregano, cilantro or any herb you particularly love. You’ll need about 1 tablespoon (about 2.5 grams) of the leafy herbs, like parsley, basil, and chives, and about 1 teaspoon (about 1 gram) of the finer herbs, like rosemary and thyme, per 1 pound (0.45 kg) of asparagus. Mix whatever herbs you’re using with about 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of cooking oil, and brush the mixture over the asparagus before you cook it. Pair the herbs with the rest of your dish to make a comprehensive meal. For example, if you’re making pizza, use basil and oregano on your asparagus for a nice accompaniment. You can also use dried herbs! The flavor just won’t be quite as strong as it would be with fresh ones. Generally, use 1/3 of the called for amount when switching to dried herbs.

steps.headline: Sprinkle on some dried spices for a smokier, richer flavor.
steps.description: Smoked paprika, chipotle powder, cumin, and curry powder can each add a distinct flavor to your asparagus. For 1 pound (0.45 kg) of asparagus, sprinkle on about 1 teaspoon (2 grams) of dried spice. Simply drizzle the asparagus with olive oil and sprinkle the seasoning overtop, and then cook the dish as normal. Pair your seasonings with the rest of your dish. For example, if you’re making Indian food for dinner, sprinkling some curry powder over your asparagus would be really tasty.

steps.headline: Mince up several cloves of garlic to add a fragrant yet simple touch.
steps.description: Fresh garlic is aromatic and adds a great flavor to many dishes, and asparagus is no exception! Use a knife to smash and mince up 1-2 cloves of garlic, and sprinkle it on the asparagus, along with olive oil, salt, and pepper. You could also use pre-minced garlic if you don’t have any fresh cloves at home.

steps.headline: Squeeze fresh lemon juice over your asparagus if you like citrus flavors.
steps.description: After your asparagus has finished cooking, simply squeeze a wedge of lemon overtop of the dish. Lemon goes well with garlic, fresh herbs, salt and pepper, so it’s a nice addition to asparagus that has been seasoned already. Lime juice can also be a fun addition to your asparagus.

methods.name: Adding In Cheeses, Nuts, or Prosciutto

steps.headline: Shave off some fresh parmesan to add to freshly grilled asparagus.
steps.description: Add parmesan to an entire dish of asparagus, or supply a bowl full of freshly shaved parmesan and let your guests add as much as they prefer. Pecorino and other hard, white cheeses would also go well with asparagus. Try to use fresh parmesan rather than the softer, crumbled kind that often pairs with pasta dishes for a sharper flavor.

steps.headline: Crumble blue cheese over warm asparagus for a melty, rich flavor.
steps.description: Take about 1 ounce (28 g) of blue cheese and crumble it overtop of 1 pound (0.45 kg) of already prepared asparagus. The heat will slightly melt the cheese, which will make it even more enjoyable to eat. If you plan on using blue cheese, use a little less salt than normal to season the asparagus, since the cheese itself will add some saltiness to the dish.

steps.headline: Sprinkle chopped nuts over asparagus for extra texture and flavor.
steps.description: Almonds, pine nuts, walnuts, pecans, sunflower seeds, pistachios—nearly every type of nut can be paired with asparagus. Simply chop up 1 ounce (28 g) of your preferred nut and sprinkle it overtop of asparagus before or after you cook it. Avoid using nuts if you’re grilling the asparagus, as they’ll be more likely to fall through the grate. It’s best to use when you bake asparagus in the oven or cook it on the stovetop.

steps.headline: Wrap asparagus in salty prosciutto to make an enticing appetizer.
steps.description: While not exactly a seasoning, prosciutto is a great way to add some extra flavor to asparagus. Simply wrap each individual stalk with a slice of prosciutto, and then bake them in a skillet over high heat for 2-3 minutes. This is a great (and easy) dish to bring along to a party or to prepare as a quick appetizer. You could also use bacon instead of prosciutto, depending on what you have on hand.

steps.headline: Add a balsamic glaze to give the asparagus a sweet and tangy taste.
steps.description: To make a balsamic glaze, all you need to do is mix 2 cups (470 mL) of balsamic vinegar with 2 cups (400 grams) of brown sugar in a sauce pan. Bring the mix to a boil, then reduce the heat so the mixture is simmering, and let it cook for about 20 minutes. Drizzle the glaze over prepared asparagus. Store leftover glaze in the fridge in a covered container for up to 2 weeks. A balsamic glaze would pair really well with some crumbled blue cheese.

steps.headline: Drizzle honey over salted asparagus for a sweet and savory flavor.
steps.description: This is super simple and delicious. Sparingly drizzle your favorite honey over top of prepared asparagus. Try pairing it with walnuts, too, for another tasty variation. Use a minimal amount of honey at first—you can always add more if you want more of the flavor, but drenching the asparagus in honey will make it too sickly-sweet.

steps.headline: Make a delicious dijon-lemon sauce for a fresh, tangy addition.
steps.description: Mix together about 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of lemon juice with ⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) of dijon mustard. Drizzle the mixture over prepared asparagus that has been seasoned with salt and pepper. Fresh parsley goes really well with the flavor of dijon and lemon, too.

steps.headline: Prepare a medley of dips to serve with asparagus for a fun dish to share.
steps.description: Prepare a dish of grilled asparagus, and serve it alongside several dipping sauces, like an herbed butter, a zesty ranch, or even a fun cranberry sauce. Lay out the platter of asparagus and put each dip into its own small bowl to create a nice spread for a party or gathering.

text: Using Herbs, Lemon, or Garlic Chop up fresh herbs for an aromatic addition to your asparagus. Use any combination of parsley, chives, rosemary, thyme, basil, oregano, cilantro or any herb you particularly love. You’ll need about 1 tablespoon (about 2.5 grams) of the leafy herbs, like parsley, basil, and chives, and about 1 teaspoon (about 1 gram) of the finer herbs, like rosemary and thyme, per 1 pound (0.45 kg) of asparagus. Pair the herbs with the rest of your dish to make a comprehensive meal. For example, if you’re making pizza, use basil and oregano on your asparagus for a nice accompaniment. You can also use dried herbs! The flavor just won’t be quite as strong as it would be with fresh ones. Generally, use 1/3 of the called for amount when switching to dried herbs. Sprinkle on some dried spices for a smokier, richer flavor. Smoked paprika, chipotle powder, cumin, and curry powder can each add a distinct flavor to your asparagus. For 1 pound (0.45 kg) of asparagus, sprinkle on about 1 teaspoon (2 grams) of dried spice. Simply drizzle the asparagus with olive oil and sprinkle the seasoning overtop, and then cook the dish as normal. Pair your seasonings with the rest of your dish. For example, if you’re making Indian food for dinner, sprinkling some curry powder over your asparagus would be really tasty. Mince up several cloves of garlic to add a fragrant yet simple touch. After your asparagus has finished cooking, simply squeeze a wedge of lemon overtop of the dish. The heat will slightly melt the cheese, which will make it even more enjoyable to eat. Simply wrap each individual stalk with a slice of prosciutto, and then bake them in a skillet over high heat for 2-3 minutes. This is a great (and easy) dish to bring along to a party or to prepare as a quick appetizer. You could also use bacon instead of prosciutto, depending on what you have on hand. Drizzle the mixture over prepared asparagus that has been seasoned with salt and pepper. Fresh parsley goes really well with the flavor of dijon and lemon, too. Lay out the platter of asparagus and put each dip into its own small bowl to create a nice spread for a party or gathering.
